text: Patient: I need two weeks off. Doctor: Yeah. No, no, no, we’ll figure it out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s just keep things moving and we’ll figure it out. Patient: So J___ told me that his promise to you is he said he’ll get me squared away medically and then - Doctor: Yes, and then it’s time for us to take over! (chuckles) Patient: Yeah. ___ called me last night. He said we’re taking a break in oncology and we’re going to do some medicine. And I said okay. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That really made me feel good, for you, too, and for me. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Because I was like “You’ve got to do that or I get derailed from what I have to do.” Patient: Right. Doctor: So he’s on it.

text: Patient: I don’t know what you think about that because that lesion is right where the nerve is pinched and I don’t know if he goes in there and stirs things up uh… Doctor: Well. Patient: He’s he’s not for sure yet. The last time I saw him he said I don’t want to open a whole can of worms and I told him if you can’t make it better… I can live with it, I can live with it. Doctor: Although their main reasoning was that there was disc issues and arthritis more the bigger problem for the nerve than… Patient: Right. Doctor: …the cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: and… Patient: But the cancer… Doctor: You know but at the time the cancer was also acting up so I said let me treat the cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Let’s see if that makes any change. text: Patient: So what’s goin’ on, so what’s goin’ on with my bones? Doctor: Nothin’. Patient: He just said that somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: No. I didn’t say anything. Patient: The other doctor that came in before him, before Dr. P_, said somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: Oh. Doctor: G_? Healthcare Professional 1: He had progression on his bone scan and CAT scan. That’s what he might have gone through. Doctor: Oh, could be. But his bones are not progressed. It’s just the, um, lymph nodes. (Pause) Patient: No. Doctor: I’m the one bringin’ it up because I see it on the scan. Oh!! We gotta do something. We gotta do something. But, from a functional day-to-day, it’s not really buggin’ you. If you were peeing poop, it would bug you. You would know it. It would frighten the heck out of everybody, but that’s not what’s happening. So, here’s a chance where we can proactively think about it and not wait until it’s an emergency. Patient: I’m not peeing poop.

text: Patient: And she started taking this fluorescence. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Are you familiar with that? Doctor: Uh-uh. What does that do? Family Member: Purifies the toxins inside your body. Patient: Detoxes, detoxification. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Family Member: Is that good for him to be taking? Doctor: Yeah. No. You’re on a medicine that interacts with everything known to mankind. XTANDI is, remember we talked about how it’s processed through the liver? So it’d be good if you don’t add on extra stuff that will tax your liver that would make the XTANDI either work less or more. More is not necessarily better, and it might make you have more side effects. Family Member: Have you heard of fluorescence? Doctor: Never heard of it. But in general we try to stay away from too many supplements on drugs like XTANDI because it is a known interactor Family Member: Oh. Oh. It’s not a drug. It’s like a homeopathic. Doctor: of many existing drugs. You have to be careful. Right. But all of those are drugs. They really are.

More is not necessarily better, and it might make you have more side effects. Family Member: Have you heard of fluorescence? Doctor: Never heard of it. Doctor: of many existing drugs. You have to be careful. Right. But all of those are drugs. They really are.

text: Patient: I, uh, I guess the one question that I had, um, reading the, the paperwork and then this conversation - You’re waiting until after the chemo and then four weeks after chemo before any spot radiation for any, any sites that have popped up. Why not treat the one spot now, that I’m, the, the rib? ‘Cuz you can’t operate there. And, I understand radiation pre-surgery on the prostate, probably not a really good thing to do and then have surgery. But, the rib - why not do the spot therapy? Doctor: Because the hormone’s gonna take care of that. The chemo is gonna take care of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The radiation is gravy. That’s the bow on top of the package. Patient: Gotcha, okay. So, it’s, it’s not a primary treatment then? Doctor: No. We’re going to everywhere the cancer is, whether we see it or we don’t see it. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, you know, then based on sort of what we do see, we’re gonna sort of pinpoint that. Patient: Okay. Tallyho. Doctor: And, so, other thoughts or questions? So, typically, what we would do is I’m gonna give you a prescription for a pill drug today. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, you take it, you take it for thirty days and then you stop. Uh, in two weeks you come in and you get your first hormone shot. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: That the cancer is shrinking. Doctor: So if his PSA drops. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So if he’s not on a clinical trial, I don’t get new pictures. Family Member: Ah, okay. Okay. Doctor: Because my sense is if you are well and your PSA’s down I assume the cancer is shrinking. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I might need pictures if we can’t your catheter is out. So what’s the problem there? Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So most of that really is just plumbing. Family Member: Right. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: Oh, I got you. Doctor: Radium, there’s liquid radiation, there’s Xofigo, which is the trade name, and, you know, we don’t give it but the radiation oncology doctors give it because it is a form of radiation. So, they’ll go over everything but what I would do is we would start the prior authorization process with our insurance but you then would talk to the radiation oncology doctor for a formal consultation and then they go over the pros and cons of what’s gonna happen and so on and so on. Patient: You know about it I’m sure about this. You know about the radiation that I had Doctor: Uh huh. Yep Patient: and is it similar to that or is the… Doctor: Different. Patient: Side effects? Doctor: You could have had the radiation. This is intravenous infusion. You know what this is, is the stuff that Marie Curie discovered all those years ago in the late eighteen hundreds. That’s what she discovered to try to treat cancer and now we actually use to treat cancer. Patient: Oh, wow! Doctor: Yeah. It’s just in smaller doses. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So, I think the fact you’ve had radiation before is not, you know, an issue.

text: Healthcare Professional: Yeah, she doesn’t start I.V.’s. They have to have the I.V. tech start them. Doctor: for chemo. HCP Okay, I’m going to take these to K____. Patient: Uh you know if you’re uh if you’re driving around in a Mercedes, the least you could do is order a nice pen. (conversation in background) Doctor: Oh my turnover of pens is crazy. I never have fancy pens because I lose them. Patient: Your husband has a bunch of ‘em. They have their nice pens. Doctor: Oh my gosh; I didn’t know that. Family Member: He said he hides them. Doctor: I guess I don’t even. I didn’t even know that. Patient: Oh yeah, because I took one when I was down there and the guy (she gets after me for swiping people’s pens) Doctor: So mine are, you’re allowed to swipe. (Laughs) Patient: Yeah, you can throw these away. (chuckles) Doctor: Well I use them so much; I mean I run out of ink and then I need to be able to toss and then move on to the next one.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
